head.title: Lithium Dendrite Suppression with a Silica Nanoparticle-Dispersed Colloidal Electrolyte | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Lithium Dendrite Suppression with a Silica Nanoparticle-Dispersed Colloidal Electrolyte

Developing a safe and long-lasting lithium (Li) metal battery is crucial for high-energy applications. However, its poor cycling stability due to Li dendrite formation and excessive Li pulverization is the major hurdle for its practical applications. Here, we present a silica (SiO2) nanoparticle-dispersed colloidal electrolyte (NDCE) and its design principle for suppressing Li dendrite formation. SiO2 nanoclusters in the NDCE play roles in enhancing the Li+ transference number and increasing the Li+ diffusivity in the vicinity of the Li-plating substrate. The NDCE enables less-dendritic Li plating by manipulating the nucleation-growth mode and extending Sand’s time. Moreover, SiO2 can interplay with the electrolyte components at the Li-metal surface, enriching fluorinated compounds in the solid electrolyte interface layer. The initial control of the Li plating morphology and SEI structure by the NDCE leads to a more uniform and denser Li deposition upon subsequent cycling, resulting in threefold enhancement of the cycle life. The efficacy of the NDCEs has been further demonstrated by the practical battery design, featuring a commercial-level cathode and thin Li-metal (40 μm) anode.

SUBJECTS:

a.title: Go to ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

img.alt: Go to ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

div.p:
Developing a safe and long-lasting lithium (Li) metal battery is crucial for high-energy applications. However, its poor cycling stability due to Li dendrite formation and excessive Li pulverization is the major hurdle for its practical applications. Here, we present a silica (SiO
2
) nanoparticle-dispersed colloidal electrolyte (NDCE) and its design principle for suppressing Li dendrite formation. SiO
2
nanoclusters in the NDCE play roles in enhancing the Li
+
transference number and increasing the Li
+
diffusivity in the vicinity of the Li-plating substrate. The NDCE enables less-dendritic Li plating by manipulating the nucleation-growth mode and extending Sand’s time. Moreover, SiO
2
can interplay with the electrolyte components at the Li-metal surface, enriching fluorinated compounds in the solid electrolyte interface layer. The initial control of the Li plating morphology and SEI structure by the NDCE leads to a more uniform and denser Li deposition upon subsequent cycling, resulting in threefold enhancement of the cycle life. The efficacy of the NDCEs has been further demonstrated by the practical battery design, featuring a commercial-level cathode and thin Li-metal (40 μm) anode.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Advances in lithium (Li) ion batteries (LIBs) have profoundly changed our lives by powering various types of portable electronics and electric vehicles. Although the maximum energy density expected from the current Li-ion chemistry cannot exceed 400 W h kg
–1
(at the cell level), the next generation of electric vehicle technology requires much higher energy density over 500 W h kg
–1
.
(1−3)
To surpass the theoretical limit of LIBs, rechargeable Li metal batteries (LMBs) have recently revisited and attracted worldwide interest to approach the milestone of 500 W h kg
–1
. Such high-energy density batteries can be designed using Li metal, which possesses very high specific capacity (3860 mA h g
–1
) and low redox potential (−3.04 V vs SHE). In this regard, the Li metal electrode is considered a “holy grail” in Li battery technology.
(4−6)

Despite its promise, Li metal still suffers from the longstanding Li dendrite problem over decades.
(7)
Dendritic Li deposition is detrimental to cycling performance and battery safety. In terms of safety concerns, sharp dendrites can potentially result in internal short circuit, triggering battery explosion.
(8)
Such a dendritic morphology increases the electrochemically active surface area and thus accelerates the parasitic reactions with electrolytes. Moreover, Li dendrites become electrochemically isolated in the subsequent Li-stripping process. A series of detrimental effects can cause lower Li metal Coulombic efficiency (CE) and shorter cycle life. Therefore, dendritic Li, as the root of catastrophic failure, should be eliminated prior to practical application of LMBs.

To break down the key fundamentals of Li metal electrodeposition, many computational studies and experimental results have demonstrated that the morphology of Li metal deposits can be determined by nucleation growth modes at the initial stage of Li electrodeposition. Its governing factors include the substrate effect,
(9)
the physical/chemical nature of the solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI),
(10)
charge kinetics (e.g., current density),
(11)
and mass transfer (e.g., Li-salt concentration, temperature, etc.).
(12)
With awareness of these key parameters, many research groups have approached this problem through compositional tuning with functional additives,
(13−15)
high-concentration electrolyte,
(16)
and single-ion conducting membrane.
(17)
In accordance with Sand’s time theory proposed by Chazalviel,
(18)
building a single-ion conducting polymer, for example, Li-Nafion, is an effective way of increasing the transference number of Li
+
cations (
t
Li
+
), resulting in extension of Sand’s time to suppress the dendrite formation.
(19)
However, Li-Nafion still suffers from low ionic conductivity (∼10
–5
S cm
–1
) and poor mechanical stability upon battery cycling. Li
+
ion conducting ceramics and glasses have been considered as alternatives, but Li dendrite growth through the grain boundary remains a key challenge.
(20)
Li surface coating with selective Li
+
ion conducting materials is also an effective approach to Li dendrite prevention.
(21)
However, excessive Li anode swelling can deteriorate the planar coating film, showing delamination and structural collapse.
(11)
Meanwhile, LiFSI-based highly concentrated electrolytes offer a facile approach to increase not only the Li
+
ion concentration in the vicinity of the Li surface but also the lithium fluoride (LiF) content in the SEI. The LiF-enriched SEI is known to enhance Li
+
surface diffusion and suppress the Li dendrite formation.
(22)
Nevertheless, there are potential concerns related to costly Li salt and high viscosity. Moreover, the anions could be depleted after prolonged cycles, resulting in out-of-charge balance and high polarization.

Here, we suggest a nanoparticle-dispersed colloidal electrolyte (NDCE) as a novel strategy to suppress the Li dendrite formation. The concept of NDCE was inspired by earlier-proposed electrolyte designs, including solid–liquid hybrid
(23,24)
and soggy-sand electrolytes.
(25,26)
These electrolytes are far different from the conventional liquid electrolytes in that nanoparticles with an electrolyte-friendly surface nature are dispersed in the host liquid electrolyte. In this work, we rationally designed highly efficient and cost-effective NDCE based on a corrosive carbonate electrolyte using commercialized fumed silica (SiO
2
) nanoparticles (∼7 nm) for LMB application. Compared with ionic liquid molecule-modified SiO
2
(23,24)
and nanodiamonds,
(27)
which were employed in previous studies, SiO
2
-based NDCEs present a stronger Li dendrite-suppressing effect under harsh operation conditions and higher practical applicability because of the use of pristine fumed SiO
2
without any chemical modification processes and the low material cost of SiO
2
. We demonstrate that the SiO
2
-incorporated NDCEs can enhance
t
Li
+
and thereby induce a denser Li deposition morphology, resulting in excellent cycling of the Li metal electrode. We further verify that an optimized NDCE endows the Li||NMC811 cell with practical design and excellent cycling stability under stringent operation conditions. Therefore, the NDCE approach can provide effective and cost-competitive means to achieve high-energy density LMBs.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Figure
1
a,b illustrate the proposed mechanism underlying the NDCE approach and the key roles of SiO
2
nanoparticles in the Li electroplating process. In the case of high-current-density operation with a conventional liquid electrolyte (
Figure
1
a), Li
+
ions are consumed immediately because of fast Li reduction (Li
+
+ e
–
→ Li), developing a strong concentration gradient near the electrode surface. If the Li ion transport from the bulk electrolyte is limited, the Li
+
ion concentration at the electrode surface can then drop to zero after a certain time. From this point (Sand’s time, τ), the Li deposit starts to grow toward the bulk electrolyte where more Li
+
ions are available, resulting in dendritic Li growth.
(18)
When the Li
+
supply from the electrolyte to the Li surface is very limited, Li dendrite growth can be accelerated.

div.p:
Figure 1. Li metal electrodeposition process with NDCEs. (a) Conventional electrolyte and (b) SiO
2
NDCE. Morphological investigation of Li metal deposition. Top surface (c,e,g) and (d,f,h) cross-sectional SEM images of electroplated Li metal obtained from control, NDCE-5, and NDCE-10, respectively. The cells were discharged at 0.5 mA cm
–2
for 1 mA h cm
–2
capacity.

div.div:
In contrast, NDCEs can alter the Li
+
ion transport mode through the percolation network of SiO
2
nanoparticle domains. As featured in
Figure
1
b, the acidic groups at the SiO
2
surface preferentially attract the Li-salt anions (PF
6
), inducing surrounding Li
+
ions to be fully dissociated from Li
+
to PF
6
–
ion pairs near the SiO
2
nanoparticles. Consequently, to further enhance Li
+
ion transport, it is crucial to increase the surface area of acidic-group-tethered SiO
2
through nanosizing and high mass loading without dispersion failure. Thus, we used commercially available 7 nm-sized fumed silica for NDCE design. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra reveal that the as-received fumed silica is decorated with acidic groups, for example, Si(OH)
x
(
Figure S1
). Moreover, its large surface area (395 m
2
g
–1
) is also beneficial to enhance the dispersion quality and Li
+
ion transport even at lower SiO
2
loading. It should be noted here that the SiO
2
nanoparticles used in this study were well-dispersed in the LiPF
6
-EC/EMC electrolyte, still remaining well-dispersed even after prolonged storage for two weeks (
Figure S2
). On the other hand, the SiO
2
dispersion in the LiPF
6
-free EC/EMC carbonate solvent was not stable, as indicated by the opacity and eventual sedimentation. Accordingly, dynamic light scattering (DLS) spectra show broad size distribution from 100 to 1000 nm (
Figure S2
). This observation indicates that the SiO
2
surface could be stabilized in the presence of Li-salt, which also supports the preferential interaction of SiO
2
nanoparticles with ionic species. The colloidal dispersion forms an effective percolation network, resulting in the overlapping of the space charge and consequent fast Li
+
ion transport through the SiO
2
nanocluster domains. The microstructure of the NDCE proposed here is similar to that of proposed models of the solid–liquid hybrid electrolyte
(23,24)
and “soggy-sand” electrolyte.
(25,26)
Therefore, SiO
2
nanoclusters can assist fast Li
+
ion transport and supply from the bulk, resulting in the retardation of Li
+
ion depletion at the electrode. These unique features of NDCE are beneficial in terms of inducing more uniform Li deposition in a less-dendritic manner.

For a proof of concept, we first investigated the morphologies of the Li metal deposits for carbonate-based NDCEs with two different levels of SiO
2
content, 5 and 10 mg mL
–1
, which are denoted as NDCE-5 and NDCE-10, respectively. Electrochemical Li deposition was conducted on Cu electrodes of corresponding Li||Cu cells at 0.5 mA cm
–2
for 2 h. As frequently reported in previous studies, the control carbonate electrolyte (LiPF
6
-EC/EMC) led to a fiber-like Li deposit (
Figure
1
c). In the cross-section view (
Figure
1
d), the apparent thickness of the Li metal deposit was much higher (∼10.5 μm) than the theoretical Li thickness (4.8 μm), being equivalent to 1 mA h cm
–2
because of its porous and fibrous morphology. Consequently, the Li deposition expands the surface area, leading to rigorous electrolyte decomposition. In strong contrast, the Li metal deposition with NDCE-5 exhibited a flat and compact Li morphology (
Figure
1
e). As shown in
Figure
1
f, the thickness of the Li metal deposit for NDCE-5 was approximately 5 μm, which is very close to the theoretical value (4.8 μm). For NDCE-10 (
Figure
1
g,h), a 6.6 μm-thick, compact Li deposition was still observed. As discussed in
Figure S3
, slight thickness variation at higher SiO
2
contents is possibly due to the codeposition of SiO
2
within the Li deposit layer. Despite thickness changes upon NDCEs, most Li electrodeposition with NDCEs still exhibits a less-dendritic, dense Li plating morphology with much lower thickness comparing with the control electrolyte.

To understand the fundamentals of the Li electrodeposition with NDCEs, we examined physical properties of the control electrolyte and the NDCEs with different SiO
2
contents (NDCE-
X
, where
X
is the number of SiO
2
concentration from 2 to 30 mg mL
–1
).
Figure
2
a compares the ionic conductivities and
t
Li
+
values determined by the Bruce–Vincent method (see
Figure S5
for details).
(24)
With the addition of 5 mg mL
–1
SiO
2
(NDCE-5),
t
Li
+
was enhanced from 0.50 to 0.70 and further increased to 0.79 by adding SiO
2
up to 20 mg mL
–1
(NDCE-20).

div.p:
Figure 2. Electrochemical characteristics of NDCEs. (a) Ionic conductivities and Li
+
transference numbers (
t
Li
+
) for the control electrolyte and NDCEs with different SiO
2
concentrations at room temperature. (b) Size intensity distribution of SiO
2
nanoclusters in LiPF
6
-EC/DEC electrolyte measured by DLS. (c) Time–current transient curves for the control electrolyte and NDCEs during chronoamperometry measurement. (d) Nondimensional plots of the chronoamperometry responses (c).

div.div:
As mentioned earlier, because the anion is preferentially absorbed on the SiO
2
surface, a colloidal dispersion of SiO
2
can facilitate the dissociation of ion pairs. Hence,
t
Li
+
enhancement in the NDCEs is mainly attributed to dissociated Li
+
ions and immobile anions tethered to the nanoparticles.
(25)
Moreover, at a higher SiO
2
concentration above percolation threshold, the percolating network can provide a fast Li
+
ion transport pathway through SiO
2
cluster domains, as illustrated in
Figure
1
b. Compared to the neat electrolyte, the bulk conductivity (σ
bulk
) of the NDCEs dropped slightly from 6.7 to 4.8 mS cm
–1
as the amount of SiO
2
increased because of the increase in viscosity (
Table S1
). At an extremely high SiO
2
amount (i.e., NDCE-30), its DLS spectra showed significant aggregation of SiO
2
nanoclusters, depicting the dispersion failure. The failure of SiO
2
dispersion and the large spatial occupation by SiO
2
can play a negative role as a steric barrier, which is detrimental to Li
+
ion transport. Nevertheless, the effective Li
+
ion conductivities (σ
eff
= σ
bulk
×
t
Li
+
) of NDCEs (4.08, 4.68, 4.23, 3.97, 3.92, and 3.73 mS cm
–1
for NDCE-2, 5, 10, 15, 20, and 30, respectively) were higher than those of the control electrolyte (3.52 mS cm
–1
). This result indicates that the well-dispersed nanoclusters (<20 mg mL
–1
) can provide multiple pathways for Li
+
ion transport along their expanded surface area. Therefore, the NDCE approach can not only enhance the Li
+
ion transport but also retard Li
+
ion depletion in the vicinity of the Li surface by supplying Li
+
ions rapidly. These beneficial features achieved by the NDCE approach mainly contributed to uniform Li deposition morphology, as observed in
Figure
1
.

For a quantitative investigation of the Li electrodeposition process with NDCEs, we performed a chronoamperometry analysis, which provides the key electrochemical parameters such as the nucleation mode, Li
+
diffusivity, and nucleus growth rate. As shown in
Figure
2
c, the current responses to a step potential (5 mV) feature the generation of a peak in the early stage followed by a gradual reduction of current, which is typical of diffusion-controlled nucleation and subsequent growth.
(29)
Figure
2
c can be converted into nondimensional plots as a function of
t
/
t
max
and of
I
/
I
max
, where
I
max
and
t
max
correspond to the maximum current and the time at the current peak, respectively. The rise in current in each transient (
t
/
t
max
≤ 1) indicates that the electroactive area increases because each independent nucleus grows in size.
(30)
According to the Scharifker–Hills (S–H) model,
(31)
two different nucleation modes can be determined: instantaneous and progressive nucleation models. Theoretical curves for instantaneous and progressive nucleation are also obtained for the determination. In principle, for instantaneous nucleation, it is assumed that all the nuclei are created as soon as the potential is applied, and the number of nucleation sites is determined at the beginning and remains constant upon step potential. For the progressive nucleation model, the nucleus continuously increases with elapsed time because of locally different activation energies. From the experimental data, the responses for the control and NDCE electrolytes are likely governed by the 3D instantaneous nucleation model. According to the equations for 3D instantaneous nucleation (
eqs 1
and
2
),
(32−34)
the Li
+
diffusivity (
D
Li
+
) and the number of nucleus (
N
) at the interface were determined, as displayed in
Table
1
.
(1)
(2)
where
F
is Faraday’s constant,
C
* is the concentration of Li ions in the electrolyte,
z
is the electrons participating in the reaction,
N
is the number of nucleus, and
k
is a constant (8π
cM
/ρ)
1/2
. As shown in
Table
1
, the
D
Li
+
value was increased by 34% with the addition of only 2 mg mL
–1
SiO
2
to the neat electrolyte. As more SiO
2
nanoparticles were added up to 20 mg mL
–1
(NDCE-20),
D
Li
+
values steadily increased by 400%. The results further support that the SiO
2
nanoparticles contribute to the improved Li transport upon the initial Li-plating process.
Figure
2
d provides the current evolution after peak current (
t
max
), which accounts for the Li
+
transport behavior at the Li-depositing surface. The control electrolyte exhibited a faster current fade after
t
max
than the NDCEs, indicating limited Li
+
diffusivity. On the other hand, the
I
/
I
max
after
t
max
remains higher for NDCEs because of the faster Li
+
supply, which is in good agreement with the increase in
D
Li
+
. The uniform and dense Li deposition with the NDCEs can be fully explained on the basis of Sand’s time theory.
(18)
Sand’s time (τ), the expected onset time for dendrite formation, is proportional to
D
Li
+
and inversely proportional to 1 –
t
Li
+
.
(28)
Therefore, the NDCEs can effectively retard the Li dendrite growth by increasing
t
Li
+
and
D
Li
+
, simultaneously.

Table 1. Values for the Maximum Current (
I
max
), the Time at the Maximum Current (

), the Number of Nucleus (

), and Li

Diffusivity on the Li-Metal Electrode (

+
)

Considering the compact Li morphology induced by SiO
2
, the NDCEs can improve the cycling stability of LMBs. For the LMB cycling, we constructed a cell composed of a LiCoO
2
(LCO) cathode (∼1.5 mA h cm
–2
) and as-prepared NDCEs with different SiO
2
contents from 5 to 20 mg mL
–1
. As shown in
Figure
3
a, even with the addition of a low amount of SiO
2
of 5 mg mL
–1
(NDCE-5), the cycling number at 80% of the initial capacity was enhanced from 106 to 167 cycles for 1 C-rate cycling (1.5 mA cm
–2
for charge/discharge). Interestingly, the cycling stability of the Li||LCO cell monotonically increased with the SiO
2
concentration. The cycle number at 80% capacity retention was 167, 246, 290, and 306 cycles for NDCE-5, 10, 15, and 20. Considering the good stability of SiO
2
at high voltage (∼4.5 V),
(35)
improved cycling performance is mainly attributed to the stabilization effect at the Li anode side. The dependency of the cycling stability on the SiO
2
content strongly suggests that the enhanced
t
Li
+
and
D
Li
+
at the interface by SiO
2
are conducive to the reversibility of the Li metal electrode. The charge/discharge curves for the control and NDCEs are compared at the 5th and 100th cycles in
Figure
3
b. At the fifth cycle, the control, NDCE-5, and NDCE-10 showed negligible differences in the charge and discharge overpotentials, whereas NDCE-15 and 20 exhibited larger polarizations at the fifth cycle because of the larger ohmic loss. After 100 cycles (
Figure
3
c), for the control electrolyte, the discharge capacity was severely reduced with an increased overpotential, which is indicative of escalation of the Li metal impedance.
(11)
However, the overpotentials of the NDCE cells did not notably increase, demonstrating higher stability of the Li electrode.

div.p:
Figure 3. Electrochemical cycling of Li||LiCoO
2
(LCO) cells with different NDCEs. (a) Capacity retention at 1 C-rate for charge/discharge (1 C = 1.5 mA cm
–2
). Voltage profiles of Li||LCO cells with NDCEs at selected cycle numbers, (b) fifth cycle and (c) 100th cycle.

div.div:
It has been reported that Li anode pulverization is the most challenging issue to address the poor reversibility and safety of prototypical Li metal pouch cells.
(36,37)
Because the anode swelling mostly occurs during the initial tens of cycles, the evolution of uniform and dense Li deposition at an early stage of cycling is critical to prevent catastrophic Li anode swelling.
(37)
In this regard, we collected cross-sectional SEM images of the cycled Li metal anodes (80 cycles) with different SiO
2
contents (
Figure
4
a–e) and compared the thickness of the cycled Li electrodes (
Figure
4
f). As shown in
Figure
4
a, the thickness of the cycled electrode was measured to be 274 μm as a result of the extensive growth of a passivation layer, which is mainly composed of accumulated SEI residues and “dead” Li.
(38)
On the other hand, the Li anode of the NDCE-5 cell shows a reduced thickness of 218 μm (
Figure
4
b). When the SiO
2
concentration increases up to 10 mg mL
–1
(NDCE-10), the thickness was further reduced to 156 μm (
Figure
4
c). These observations indicate that the less-dendritic Li morphology induced by the NDCEs is very effective to mitigate the extensive growth of the passivation layer and thereby enhance the cycling stability upon prolonged cycling. At higher SiO
2
content (NDCE-15 and 20), however, such a thickness reduction with SiO
2
content was not observed. Therefore, the Li morphology effect cannot fully explain the increased cycle numbers with SiO
2
at high SiO
2
content, suggesting the existence of another effect.

We expect that chemical modification of the SEI is the other factor influencing the cycling stability. As shown in
Figure S4
, we observed that SiO
2
nanoparticles remained at the electrode even after the Li-stripping process, suggesting that these SiO
2
nanoparticles were partially embedded in the SEI residue. The observation also presents a possibility that SiO
2
can contribute to the compositional changes of the SEI. Recently, it was reported that the SiO
2
concentrated at the surface of silicon can facilitate the formation of a LiF-rich SEI layer.
(39)
To reveal the effect of SiO
2
on SEI modification, we carried out an XPS analysis for the SEI after the first cycle with the control electrolyte and NDCE-5, 10, 15, and 20 (
Figure
5
). The C 1s spectra reveal four major peaks, which can be assigned to C–C (284.8 eV), ether (286.8 eV), ester (289.1 eV), and alkyl carbonate (290.3 eV). Although the control and NDCE-5 cell did not reveal obvious differences, for NDCE-10, 15, and 20, the intensities of the four peaks decreased with the SiO
2
content. The atomic percentage of the C element steadily decreased with the SiO
2
content (
Table S2
), indicating that SiO
2
alleviates the decomposition of the carbonate solvents. In the O 1s spectra, the intensity of O compounds increased with the SiO
2
content, and in the Si 2p
3/2
spectra, the signals from Si compounds appeared only for the NDCEs. These results suggest that SiO
2
is involved in the formation of the SEI.

div.p:
Figure 5. High-resolution XPS spectra for the SEI formed after the first Li-stripping process. For the sample preparation, Li||Cu cells were assembled with the neat electrolyte (control cell) and NDCEs with different SiO
2
concentrations. Li metal was plated for 1 h and stripped up to 1.0 V at 0.5 mA cm
–2
.

div.div:
The most obvious spectral change with the SiO
2
content was observed in the F 1s spectra. The spectra show two characteristic peaks at LiF (685 eV) and Li
x
PO
y
F
z
(687.8 eV).
(40)
The formation of Li
x
PO
y
F
z
is also confirmed by the peak at 134.2 eV in the P 2p spectra. In general, these compounds originate from the chemical breakdown of the LiPF
6
salt at the Li metal anode through the following
reactions 4
–
6
(39,40)
(4)
(5)
(6)

The intensities of LiF and Li
x
PO
y
F
z
peaks in both F 1s and P 2p spectra were dramatically enhanced at SiO
2
content higher than 10 mg mL
–1
, which suggests that SiO
2
contributes to the formation of the fluorine compounds in addition to the intrinsic chemical breakdown of LiPF
6
.

In the Si 2p spectra, NDCE-5 exhibits only single Si 2p peak at ∼101.9 eV, which is attributed to the Si–O bond of SiO
2
. As discussed earlier, SiO
2
can be codeposited to some extent and embedded in the SEI residue even after the Li-stripping process. The SiO
2
content increases over 10 mg mL
–1
; however, the new 2p peak at 105 eV emerges, which can be assigned as fluorosilicates (Li
x
SiF
y
) and the peak intensity steadily increases. It seems that the compositional change of the SEI can be triggered beyond a SiO
2
concentration threshold (>10 mg mL
–1
). The behaviors suggest the occurrence of chemical etching of SiO
2
by HF to form SiF
4
(
reaction 7
) and a subsequent reaction of SiF
4
to form hexafluorosilicate (Li
2
SiF
6
) (
reaction 8
). The fluorosilicates can further react with lithium hydroxide (LiOH), which is one of the major components of the native passivation film of Li metal, and enrich LiF and Li orthosilicate (Li
4
SiO
4
) in the SEI layer (
reaction 9
).
(7)
(8)
(9)

LiF in the SEI layer is known to promote Li
+
transport because of its high ionic conductivity of ∼10
–7
S cm
–1
, facilitating more uniform Li deposition. Additionally, Li
4
SiO
4
can stabilize the negative electrodes because of its excellent high ionic conductivity and electrochemical stability, which is why it has been studied as a solid-state electrolyte,
(41)
a coating material for high-voltage cathodes,
(42)
and an artificial protective layer on Si and Li metal anodes.
(43,44)
After 80 cycles, the NDCE cells showed higher content of the F compounds than the control cell, as shown in
Figure S6 and Table S2
. The XPS analyses explain the enhanced cycling stability of the Li||LCO cells with the SiO
2
content in terms of the formation of a F-rich SEI and consequent suppression of electrolyte decomposition.

The XPS analysis indicates that the selection of the Li salt anion is crucial to determine the SEI structures for the NDCE. To understand how the LiF formation influences the Li cycling stability for the NDCE, Li||LiCoO
2
(LCO) cells, NDCEs based on LiClO
4
were examined with varying SiO
2
content. With increasing SiO
2
content, the cycling stability was enhanced (
Figure S7
), as observed for the NDCEs based on LiPF
6
. This demonstrates the importance of high
t
Li
+
and
D
Li
+
for Li metal cycling stability. However, compared with the LiPF
6
-based NDCEs, the cycling stabilities of the LiClO
4
-based NDCEs were inferior at the same SiO
2
content. This indicates that the formation of a stable LiF-rich SEI significantly contributes to the enhanced reversibility of the Li metal electrode. Therefore, the SiO
2
nanoparticles in the LiPF
6
-containing NDCEs play a synergistic role in inducing a less-dendritic Li plating morphology and chemical modification of the SEI. Because of this combined effect, the pulverization of the Li metal electrode can be effectively suppressed upon prolonged cycling.

For achieving high energy density at the cell level, high cathode loading and the use of a thin Li anode are essential.
(37,45)
To further validate the efficacy of the NDCE, a Li(Ni
0.8
Mn
0.1
Co
0.1
)O
2
(NMC811) cathode with a high areal capacity of 4.2 mA h cm
–2
and a thin Li anode (40 μm, ∼7.8 mA h cm
–2
) was employed for the LMB. The negative/positive (N/P) capacity ratio was only 1.9 in this case. When the formation of the SEI and inactive Li is respectively significant per each cycle, severe capacity fading occurs with cycling.
(46)
As shown in
Figure
6
, the Li||NMC811 cell with the LiPF
6
-EC/EMC electrolyte showed fast capacity fading at early cycles with a capacity retention of 80% at 44 cycles. In strong contrast, the Li||NMC811 cells with NDCEs unequivocally exhibited improved capacity retention compared with the control cell. Even at the low SiO
2
content of 5 mg mL
–1
(NDCE-5), the cycling at 80% capacity retention was greatly improved from 44 to 82 cycles. Further increase in the SiO
2
content up to 15 mg mL
–1
resulted in an increase in the capacity retention at the 100th cycle from 61% (NDCE-5) to 85% (NDCE-15).

div.p:
Figure 6. Cycling of Li||Li(Ni
0.8
Mn
0.1
Co
0.1
)O
2
(Li||NMC811) cells with NDCEs. The cells are composed of a thick NMC811 cathode (areal capacity: 4.2 mA h cm
–2
) and 40 μm-thick Li anode (areal capacity: 7.8 mA h cm
–2
), corresponding to 1.9 N/P ratio. The cycling test was performed at 0.2 and 0.5 C-rates for charge and discharge, respectively.

div.div:
Contrary to the Li||LCO cell cycling results (
Figure
3
), NDCE-15 exhibits the most stable cycling in a Li||NMC811 cell configuration. In a high-energy-density LMB configuration, the depletion rate of Li
+
available in the cell and the build-up rate of cell impedance are determining factors for the cycling performance.
(47)
If excess Li (∼150 μm thickness) is provided, like previous Li||LCO cell testing, CE and cycle life will be readily improved as long as the cell impedance is still not high enough to terminate the cell. However, the available Li
+
source in the Li||NMC811 cell is very limited, compared to that in Li||LCO cell. Thus, Li||NMC811 cells suffer from quick Li consumption and fast build-up rate of cell impedance because of significant side reactions within the cell. The base electrolyte of NDCEs in this study is the carbonate electrolyte (LiPF
6
-EC/EMC), which is still corrosive to the Li metal anode. Furthermore, at the higher areal capacity of NMC811, the absolute value of the current density becomes higher even at the same C-rate. Because the high viscosity of NDCE, especially at higher SiO
2
concentration (≥20 mg mL
–1
), can directly contribute to the cell impedance (see
Figure S8
), the viscosity of NDCE becomes a greater impact on the cycling performance. Therefore, less-dendritic, dense Li deposition with efficient SEI build-up at moderate viscosity is the key to enhance the cycling performance of Li||NMC811 cells. In this regard, the SiO
2
content should be further optimized depending on the cell configuration and operating conditions.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In summary, we have proposed an NDCE approach to suppress Li dendrite growth and improve the cycling performance of LMBs. In the NDCEs, SiO
2
nanoparticles with an acidic surface nature can attract Li-salt anions and enhance the Li
+
transference number (∼0.79) without less sacrifice of the Li
+
ion conductivity, resulting in a less-dendritic and denser structure of the Li deposit. In addition to the morphological control of the Li deposit, the NDCE can modify the SEI structure by enriching LiF, Li
x
SiF
y
, and Li silicates (Li
x
SiO
y
). With the combined effect of a high Li
+
transference number and highly fluorinated SEI, the cycling stability of the LMB (Li||LCO) was improved threefold. The practical applicability of the NDCE approach was further demonstrated with a prototype LMB (Li||NMC811) with an NMC811 cathode (4.2 mA h cm
–2
) and 40 μm-thick Li. Benefiting from the dense and uniform Li deposition and the fluoride-enriched SEI layer, NDCEs can pave the way to higher cycling stability and better safety of LMBs.

-based NDCEs; cycling performance of NDCE cells at 3 C-rate; quantitative atomic concentration tables of SEI layers as measured by XPS; and F 1s XPS spectra for cycled Li anodes after 80 cycles with different electrolytes (

Enabling the reversible lithium metal electrode is essential for surpassing the energy content of today's lithium-ion cells. Although lithium metal cells for niche applications have been developed already, efforts are underway to create rechargeable lithium metal batteries that can significantly advance vehicle electrification and grid energy storage. In this Perspective, we focus on three tasks to guide and further advance the reversible lithium metal electrode. First, we summarize the state of research and com. efforts in terms of four key performance parameters, and identify addnl. performance parameters of interest. We then advocate for the use of limited lithium (≤30 μm) to ensure early identification of tech. challenges assocd. with stable and dendrite-free cycling and a more rapid transition to com. relevant designs. Finally, we provide a cost target and outline material costs and manufg. methods that could allow lithium metal cells to reach 100 US$ kWh-1.

It is widely accepted that for elec. vehicles to be accepted by consumers and to achieve wide market penetration, ranges of at least 500 km at an affordable cost are required. Therefore, significant improvements to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) in terms of energy d. and cost along the battery value chain are required, while other key performance indicators, such as lifetime, safety, fast-charging ability and low-temp. performance, need to be enhanced or at least sustained. Here, we review advances and challenges in LIB materials for automotive applications, in particular with respect to cost and performance parameters. The prodn. processes of anode and cathode materials are discussed, focusing on material abundance and cost. Advantages and challenges of different types of electrolyte for automotive batteries are examd. Finally, energy densities and costs of promising battery chemistries are critically evaluated along with an assessment of the potential to fulfil the ambitious targets of elec. vehicle propulsion.

Li-ion batteries have transformed portable electronics and will play a key role in the electrification of transport. However, the highest energy storage possible for Li-ion batteries is insufficient for the long-term needs of society, for example, extended-range elec. vehicles. To go beyond the horizon of Li-ion batteries is a formidable challenge; there are few options. Here Li-air (O2) and Li-S batteries are considered. The energy that can be stored in Li-air (based on aq. or non-aq. electrolytes) and Li-S cells is compared with Li-ion; the operation of the cells is discussed, as are the significant hurdles that will have to be overcome if such batteries are to succeed. Fundamental scientific advances in understanding the reactions occurring in the cells as well as new materials are key to overcoming these obstacles. The potential benefits of Li-air and Li-S justify the continued research effort that will be needed.

A review is given. Li-ion batteries have had a profound impact on our daily life, but inherent limitations make it difficult for Li-ion chemistries to meet the growing demands for portable electronics, elec. vehicles and grid-scale energy storage. Therefore, chemistries beyond Li-ion are currently being investigated and need to be made viable for com. applications. The use of metallic Li is one of the most favored choices for next-generation Li batteries, esp. Li-S and Li-air systems. After falling into oblivion for several decades because of safety concerns, metallic Li is now ready for a revival, thanks to the development of investigative tools and nanotechnol.-based solns. Here, we 1st summarize the current understanding on Li anodes, then highlight the recent key progress in materials design and advanced characterization techniques, and finally discuss the opportunities and possible directions for future development of Li anodes in applications.

A review. Tremendous progress has been made in the development of lithium-based rechargeable batteries in recent decades. Discoveries of new electrode materials as well as new storage mechanisms have substantially improved battery performance. In particular, nanomaterials design has emerged as a promising soln. to tackle many fundamental problems in conventional battery materials. Here we discuss in detail several key issues in batteries, such as electrode vol. change, solid-electrolyte interphase formation, electron and ion transport, and electrode atom/mol. movement, and then analyze the advantages presented by nanomaterials design. In addn., we discuss the challenges caused by using nanomaterials in batteries, including undesired parasitic reactions with electrolytes, low volumetric and areal energy d., and high costs from complex multi-step processing, and their possible solns.

A review. Li electrodes in any relevant electrolyte soln. (i.e., polar aprotic) are covered by surface films of a very complicated structure. It was found that even in cases where the surface films formed on lithium contain elastomers, or where the lithium metal reactivity is reduced by doping with elements such as N, As, Al, Mg, Ca, etc., it is impossible to achieve sufficient passivation with lithium electrodes and liq. solns. Passivation is considerably worsened when Li electrodes are operated at high rates (esp. at high charging, Li deposition rates). Thus, there is no way that rechargeable Li batteries can compete with Li-ion batteries in any application that requires high charging rates (e.g., in powering portable electronic devices). The electrochem. behavior of lithiated graphite electrodes also depends on passivation phenomena. The surface films formed on lithiated graphite are similar to those formed on Li metal in the same solns. The vol. changes of graphite electrodes during Li insertion-deinsertion are small enough to enable their reasonable passivation in a variety of electrolyte solns. A crit. factor that dets. the stability of graphite electrodes is their morphol. It was found that the shape of graphite particles plays a key role in their application as active mass in anodes for Li-ion batteries.

The authors demonstrated that an artificial Li3PO4 solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer with high Young's modulus can restrain Li dendrite growth and reduce the side reaction between Li metal and the org. electrolyte. The Li3PO4 SEI layer exhibits high chem. stability during the Li deposition/dissoln. process without a breakage and repair mechanism. The uniform Li3PO4 SEI layer effectively restrains Li dendrite growth and reduces the corrosion of bulk Li after 200 cycles in a Li|LiFePO4 battery. The artificial SEI strategy is a promising route to tackle the intrinsic problems of Li metal anodes and other metal-based anodes.

Dendritic growth of Li during galvanostatic electrodeposition is modeled. The time-dependent concn. distribution near the Li surface is computed by numerically solving the transport equation inside the diffusion boundary layer. The dendrite propagation rate, i.e., the dendrite tip c.d., is calcd. by analyzing the various overpotentials that develop at the dendrite tip and at the flat electrode surface. The surface overpotential at the dendrite tip due to its radius of curvature is also incorporated in the model; however, for typical dendrite tip radii, this surface overpotential is very small. The dendrite tip propagation rate predicted by the model agrees reasonably well with exptl. data from the literature. For dendritic growth under pure activation control, a simplified anal. expression for the tip c.d. is derived. The anal. expression shows that dendritic growth is suppressed in systems that exhibit a lower charge transfer coeff.

The effects of some film-forming org. additives, fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC), vinylene carbonate (VC), and ethylene sulfite (ES), on Li deposition and dissoln. were studied in 1 M LiClO4 dissolved in propylene carbonate (PC) as a base soln. When 5% FEC was added, the cycling efficiency was improved. On the contrary, addn. of 5% VC or ES significantly lowered the cycling efficiency. The surface morphol. of Li deposited in each electrolyte soln. was obsd. by in situ at. force microscopy (AFM). In PC+FEC, the surface was covered with a uniform and closely packed layer of particle-like deposits of ∼100-150 nm diam. The surface film seemed to be more solid in PC+VC, and inhomogeneous in PC+ES. From a.c. impedance measurements, the surface film formed in PC+FEC has a lower resistance than that in the additive-free soln., whereas that formed in PC+VC or PC+ES has a higher resistance. Large vol. changes during Li deposition and dissoln. require that the surface film should be elastic (or soft) and be self-repairable when being damaged. A nonuniform current distribution is liable to cause dendrite formation, which requires that the surface film should be uniform and its resistance should be as low as possible. PC+FEC gave a surface film that satisfies all these requirements, and therefore only FEC was effective as an additive for deposition and dissoln. of Li metal.

Liquid electrolyte plays a key role in commercial lithium-ion batteries to allow conduction of lithium-ion between cathode and anode. Traditionally, taking into account the ionic conductivity, viscosity and dissolubility of lithium salt, the salt concentration in liquid electrolytes is typically less than 1.2 mol l(-1). Here we show a new class of 'Solvent-in-Salt' electrolyte with ultrahigh salt concentration and high lithium-ion transference number (0.73), in which salt holds a dominant position in the lithium-ion transport system. It remarkably enhances cyclic and safety performance of next-generation high-energy rechargeable lithium batteries via an effective suppression of lithium dendrite growth and shape change in the metallic lithium anode. Moreover, when used in lithium-sulphur battery, the advantage of this electrolyte is further demonstrated that lithium polysulphide dissolution is inhibited, thus overcoming one of today's most challenging technological hurdles, the 'polysulphide shuttle phenomenon'. Consequently, a coulombic efficiency nearing 100% and long cycling stability are achieved.

The inhomogeneous Li electrodeposition of lithium metal electrode has been a major impediment to the realization of rechargeable lithium metal batteries. Although single ion conducting ionomers can induce more homogeneous Li electrodeposition by preventing Li+ depletion at Li surface, currently available materials do not allow room-temp. operation due to their low room temp. conductivities. In the paper, we report that a highly conductive ionomer/liq. electrolyte hybrid layer tightly laminated on Li metal electrode can realize stable Li electrodeposition at high current densities up to 10 mA cm-2 and permit room-temp. operation of corresponding Li metal batteries with low polarizations. The hybrid layer is fabricated by laminating few micron-thick Nafion layer on Li metal electrode followed by soaking 1 M LiPF6 EC/DEC (1/1) electrolyte. The Li/Li sym. cell with the hybrid layer stably operates at a high c.d. of 10 mA cm-2 for more than 2000 h, which corresponds to more than five-fold enhancement compared with bare Li metal electrode. Also, the prototype Li/LiCoO2 battery with the hybrid layer offers cycling stability more than 350 cycles. These results demonstrate that the hybrid strategy successfully combines the advantages of bi-ionic liq. electrolyte (fast Li+ transport) and single ionic ionomer (prevention of Li+ depletion).

To suppress dendrite formation in lithium metal batteries, high cation transference number electrolytes that reduce electrode polarization are highly desirable, but rarely available using conventional liquid electrolytes. Here, we show that liquid electrolytes increase their cation transference numbers (e.g., ∼0.2 to >0.70) when confined to a structurally rigid polymer host whose pores are on a similar length scale (0.5-2 nm) as the Debye screening length in the electrolyte, which results in a diffuse electrolyte double layer at the polymer-electrolyte interface that retains counterions and reject co-ions from the electrolyte due to their larger size. Lithium anodes coated with ∼1 μm thick overlayers of the polymer host exhibit both a low area-specific resistance and clear dendrite-suppressing character, as evident from their performance in Li-Li and Li-Cu cells as well as in post-mortem analysis of the anode's morphology after cycling. High areal capacity Li-S cells (4.9 mg cm(-2); 8.2 mAh cm(-2)) implementing these high transference number polymer-hosted liquid electrolytes were remarkably stable, considering ∼24 μm of lithium was electroreversibly deposited in each cycle at a C-rate of 0.2. We further identified a scalable manufacturing path for these polymer-coated lithium electrodes, which are drop-in components for lithium metal battery manufacturing.

We report org.-inorg. hybrid ionic liq. electrolytes for lithium-metal secondary batteries (LMBs) and study their effect on lithium dendrite proliferation. Formed by blending silica nanoparticles densely functionalized with ionic liq. 1-methyl-3-propylimidazolium bis(trifluoromethanesulfone)imide (SiO2-IL-TFSI) with a conventional propylene carbonate/LiTFSI based liq. electrolyte, such electrolytes potentially offer at least two unique mechanisms for suppressing lithium dendrites. First, if the tethered ionic liq. mols. can dissoc. to release anions in the electrolyte, the nanoparticles might serve as reservoirs for anions in a cell, which can migrate to delay/prevent development of a space charge. Second, beyond particle concns. near the percolation threshold, the impermeable nanometer-sized particles form a porous mesh that provides a mech. strong and highly tortuous path through which nucleated dendrites must grow to short-circuit the cell. We find that at all nanoparticle compns. the SiO2-IL-TFSI/propylene carbonate hybrids exhibit substantially improved electrochem. and interfacial properties. The hybrids also show enhanced ability to retard proliferation of lithium dendrites in LMBs. We also create and characterize LMBs based on the IL-hybrid electrolytes and find that they are promising candidates for both high-energy Li/MoS2 and high-power Li/TiO2 secondary batteries.

Development of rechargeable lithium metal battery (LMB) remains a challenge because of uneven lithium deposition during repeated cycles of charge and discharge. Ionic liqs. have received intensive scientific interest as electrolytes because of their exceptional thermal and electrochem. stabilities. Ionic liq. and ionic-liq.-nanoparticle hybrid electrolytes based on 1-methy-3-propylimidazolium (IM) and 1-methy-3-propylpiperidinium (PP) were synthesized and their ionic cond., electrochem. stability, mech. properties, and ability to promote stable Li electrodeposition studied. PP-based electrolytes are more conductive and substantially more efficient in suppressing dendrite formation on cycled lithium anodes; ≥11 wt.% PP-IL in a PC-LiTFSI host produces more than a 10-fold increase in cell lifetime. Both PP- and IM-based nanoparticle hybrid electrolytes provide up to 10,000-fold improvements in cell lifetime than anticipated based on their mech. modulus alone. Galvanostatic cycling measurements in Li/Li4Ti5O12 half cells using IL-nanoparticle hybrid electrolytes reveal >500 cycles of trouble-free operation and enhanced rate capability.

A review. Soggy-sand electrolytes (solid-liq. composites, typically gel electrolytes, with synergistic elec. properties) are reviewed as far as status and perspectives are concerned. Major emphasis is put on the understanding of the local mechanism as well as the long-range transport along the filler network. The beneficial property spectrum includes enhanced cond. of one ion type and decreased cond. of the counter ion, but also the exciting mech. properties of the solid-liq. composites. Inherent but not insurmountable problems lie in the reproducibility and stationarity of the composites microstructure and morphol. Owing to the huge parameter complexity and hence to the multitude of adjusting screws, there are various strategies for materials optimization. The technol. relevance is enormous, in particular for battery electrolytes as here all the above-mentioned elec. and mech. benefits are welcome. The soggy-sand electrolytes combine high Li+ cond., low anion cond. and good wettability of electrode particles with the mech. stability of semi-solids.

A review. Soggy sand electrolyte, which essentially consists of oxide dispersions in nonaq. liq. salt solns., comprises an important class of soft matter electrolytes. The ion transport mechanism of soggy sand electrolyte is complex. The configuration of particles in the liq. soln. depends in a nontrivial manner on various parameters related to the oxide (concn., size, surface chem.) and solvent (dielec. const., viscosity) as well as time. The state of the particles in soln. not only affects ionic cond. but also effectively the mech. and electrochem. properties of the solid-liq. composite. Apart from comprehensive understanding of the underlying phenomena that govern ion transport, which will benefit design of better electrolytes, the problem has far-reaching implications in diverse fields such as catalysis, colloid chem., and biotechnol.

Nanodiamonds suppress the growth of lithium dendrites
Cheng Xin-Bing; Zhao Meng-Qiang; Chen Chi; Pentecost Amanda; Maleski Kathleen; Mathis Tyler; Gogotsi Yury; Cheng Xin-Bing; Zhang Xue-Qiang; Zhang Qiang; Chen Chi; Jiang Jianjun

Lithium metal has been regarded as the future anode material for high-energy-density rechargeable batteries due to its favorable combination of negative electrochemical potential and high theoretical capacity. However, uncontrolled lithium deposition during lithium plating/stripping results in low Coulombic efficiency and severe safety hazards. Herein, we report that nanodiamonds work as an electrolyte additive to co-deposit with lithium ions and produce dendrite-free lithium deposits. First-principles calculations indicate that lithium prefers to adsorb onto nanodiamond surfaces with a low diffusion energy barrier, leading to uniformly deposited lithium arrays. The uniform lithium deposition morphology renders enhanced electrochemical cycling performance. The nanodiamond-modified electrolyte can lead to a stable cycling of lithium lithium symmetrical cells up to 150 and 200 h at 2.0 and 1.0 mA cm(-2), respectively. The nanodiamond co-deposition can significantly alter the lithium plating behavior, affording a promising route to suppress lithium dendrite growth in lithium metal-based batteries.Lithium metal is an ideal anode material for rechargeable batteries but suffer from the growth of lithium dendrites and low Coulombic efficiency. Here the authors show that nanodiamonds serve as an electrolyte additive to co-deposit with lithium metal and suppress the formation of dendrites.

High lithium transference no., tLi+, electrolytes are desired for use in both lithium-ion and lithium metal rechargeable battery technologies. Historically, low tLi+ electrolytes have hindered device performance by allowing ion concn. gradients within the cell, leading to high internal resistances that ultimately limit cell lifetime, charging rates, and energy d. Herein, we report on the synthesis and electrochem. features of electrolytes based on nanoparticle salts designed to provide high tLi+. . The salts are created by cofunctionalization of metal oxide nanoparticles with neutral org. ligands and tethered lithium salts. When dispersed in a conducting fluid such as tetraglyme, they spontaneously form a charged, nanoporous network of particles at moderate nanoparticle loadings. Modification of the tethered anion chem. from -SO3- to -SO3BF3- is shown to enhance ionic cond. of the electrolytes by facilitating ion pair dissocn. At a particle vol. fraction of 0.15, the electrolyte exists as a self-supported, nanoporous gel with an optimum ionic cond. of 10-4 S/cm at room temp. Galvanostatic polarization measurements on sym. lithium metal cells contg. the electrolyte show that the cell short circuit time, tSC, is inversely proportional to the square of the applied c.d. tSC ∼ J-2, consistent with previously predicted results for traditional polymer-in-salt electrolytes with low tLi+. . Our findings suggest that electrolytes with tLi+ ≈ 1 and good ion-pair dissocn. delay lithium dendrite nucleation and may lead to improved lithium plating in rechargeable batteries with metallic lithium anodes.

Next-generation high-energy batteries will require a rechargeable lithium metal anode, but lithium dendrites tend to form during recharging, causing short-circuit risk and capacity loss, by mechanisms that still remain elusive. Here, we visualize lithium growth in a glass capillary cell and demonstrate a change of mechanism from root-growing mossy lithium to tip-growing dendritic lithium at the onset of electrolyte diffusion limitation. In sandwich cells, we further demonstrate that mossy lithium can be blocked by nanoporous ceramic separators, while dendritic lithium can easily penetrate nanopores and short the cell. Our results imply a fundamental design constraint for metal batteries ("Sand's capacity"), which can be increased by using concd. electrolytes with stiff, permeable, nanoporous separators for improved safety.

Nucleation, aggregative growth and detachment of metal nanoparticles during electrodeposition at electrode surfaces
Lai, Stanley C. S.; Lazenby, Robert A.; Kirkman, Paul M.; Unwin, Patrick R.

The nucleation and growth of metal nanoparticles (NPs) on surfaces is of considerable interest with regard to creating functional interfaces with myriad applications. Yet, key features of these processes remain elusive and are undergoing revision. Here, the mechanism of the electrodeposition of silver on basal plane highly oriented pyrolytic graphite (HOPG) is investigated as a model system at a wide range of length scales, spanning electrochem. measurements from the macroscale to the nanoscale using scanning electrochem. cell microscopy (SECCM), a pipet-based approach. The macroscale measurements show that the nucleation process cannot be modelled as either truly instantaneous or progressive, and that step edge sites of HOPG do not play a dominant role in nucleation events compared to the HOPG basal plane, as has been widely proposed. Moreover, nucleation nos. extd. from electrochem. anal. do not match those detd. by at. force microscopy (AFM). The high time and spatial resoln. of the nanoscale pipet set-up reveals individual nucleation and growth events at the graphite basal surface that are resolved and analyzed in detail. Based on these results, corroborated with complementary microscopy measurements, we propose that a nucleation-aggregative growth-detachment mechanism is an important feature of the electrodeposition of silver NPs on HOPG. These findings have major implications for NP electrodeposition and for understanding electrochem. processes at graphitic materials generally.

Polypyrrole is a material with immensely useful properties suitable for a wide range of electrochem. applications, but its development was hindered by cumbersome manufg. processes. A simple modification to the std. electrochem. polymn. method produces polypyrrole films of equivalently high cond. and superior mech. properties in 1-tenth of the polymn. time. Prepg. the film as electrodeposited layers with thorough solvent washing between layering was found to produce excellent quality films even when layer deposition were accelerated by high current. The washing step between the sequentially polymd. layers altered the deposition mechanism, eliminating the typical dendritic growth and generating nonporous deposits. Solvent washing reduces the concn. of oligomeric species in the near-electrode region and hinder the three-dimensional growth mechanism that occurs by deposition of secondary particles from soln. As artificial muscles, the high d. sequentially polymd. films produced the highest mech. work output yet reported for polypyrrole actuators.

State-of-the-art lithium (Li)-ion batteries are approaching their specific energy limits yet are challenged by the ever-increasing demand of today's energy storage and power applications, esp. for elec. vehicles. Li metal is considered an ultimate anode material for future high-energy rechargeable batteries when combined with existing or emerging high-capacity cathode materials. However, much current research focuses on the battery materials level, and there have been very few accounts of cell design principles. Here we discuss crucial conditions needed to achieve a specific energy higher than 350 Wh kg-1, up to 500 Wh kg-1, for rechargeable Li metal batteries using high-nickel-content lithium nickel manganese cobalt oxides as cathode materials. We also provide an anal. of key factors such as cathode loading, electrolyte amt. and Li foil thickness that impact the cell-level cycle life. Furthermore, we identify several important strategies to reduce electrolyte-Li reaction, protect Li surfaces and stabilize anode architectures for long-cycling high-specific-energy cells.

Lithium metal anodes have attracted much attention as candidates for high-energy batteries, but there have been few reports of long cycling behavior, and the degrdn. mechanism of realistic high-energy Li metal cells remains unclear. Here, we develop a prototypical 300 Wh kg-1 (1.0 Ah) pouch cell by integrating a Li metal anode, a LiNi0.6Mn0.2Co0.2O2 cathode and a compatible electrolyte. Under small uniform external pressure, the cell undergoes 200 cycles with 86% capacity retention and 83% energy retention. In the initial 50 cycles, flat Li foil converts into large Li particles that are entangled in the solid-electrolyte interphase, which leads to rapid vol. expansion of the anode (cell thickening of 48%). As cycling continues, the external pressure helps the Li anode maintain good contact between the Li particles, which ensures a conducting percolation pathway for both ions and electrons, and thus the electrochem. reactions continue to occur. Accordingly, the solid Li particles evolve into a porous structure, which manifests in substantially reduced cell swelling by 19% in the subsequent 150 cycles.

The rechargeable Li batteries with higher energy capacity and longer cycle life are necessary for application in portable electronic devices, elec. vehicles and implantable medical devices. Si is an attractive anode material for Li batteries because it has a low discharge potential and the highest known theor. charge capacity - 4,200 mA-h/g. Although this is >10 times higher than existing graphite anodes and much larger than various nitride and oxide materials, Si anodes have limited applications because Si's vol. changes by 400% upon insertion and extn. of Li which results in pulverization and capacity fading. Si nanowire electrodes circumvent these issues as they can accommodate large strain without pulverization, provide good electronic contact and conduction and have short Li insertion distances. The authors achieved the theor. charge capacity for Si anodes and maintained a discharge capacity close to 75% of this max. with little fading during cycling.

Interfacial stability is one of the crucial factors for long-term cyclability of Li metal batteries (LMBs). While cross-contamination phenomena have been well-studied in Li-ion batteries (LIBs), similar phenomena have rarely been reported in LMBs. Here, we study cathode failure triggered by chem. crossover from the anode in LMBs. In contrast to LIBs, the cathode in LMBs suffers more significant capacity fading, and its capacity cannot be fully recovered by replacing the Li anode. In-depth surface characterization reveals severe deterioration related to the accumulation of highly resistive polymeric components in the cathode-electrolyte interphase. The sol. byproducts generated by extensive electrolyte decompn. at the Li metal surface can diffuse toward the cathode side, resulting in severe deterioration of the cathode and separator surfaces. A selective Li-ion permeable separator with a polydopamine coating has been developed to mitigate the detrimental chem. crossover and enhance the cathode stability.

Nanostructured Si-based materials are key building blocks for next-generation energy storage devices. To meet the requirements of practical energy storage devices, Si-based materials should exhibit high-power, low vol. change, and high tap d. So far, there have been no reliable materials reported satisfying all of these requirements. Here, we report a novel Si-based multicomponent design, in which the Si core is covered with multifunctional shell layers. The synergistic coupling of Si with the multifunctional shell provides vital clues for satisfying all Si anode requirements for practical batteries. The Si-based multicomponent anode delivers a high capacity of ∼1000 mA h g-1, a highly stable cycling retention (∼65% after 1000 cycles at 1 C), an excellent rate capability (∼800 mA h g-1 at 10 C), and a remarkably suppressed vol. expansion (12% after 100 cycles). Our synthetic process is simple, low-cost, and safe, facilitating new methods for developing electrode materials for practical energy storage.

Lithium (Li)-metal batteries have regained broad interest in the battery research community. Although many studies on Li anode have been published in recent years, it is difficult to evaluate and compare these advances for practical applications. A key challenge is a gap between materials and component properties and the achievable large-format cell-level performance. In this paper, we investigate the crit. exptl. parameters that det. the cycle no. of coin cells to understand the performance variations reported in the literature. To define the range of cell parameters, we exemplify a representative Li-metal pouch cell with specific energy of 300 Wh/kg to provide an effective validation of electrode materials and accurate cell performance evaluations. Based on the pouch-cell-level requirements, we propose a set of coin-cell parameters and testing conditions to expedite the discovery of new materials and their full integration into realistic battery systems.

Lithium (Li) metal batteries (LMBs) have recently attracted extensive interest in the energy-storage field after silence from the public view for several decades. However, many challenges still need to be overcome before their practical application, esp. those that are related to the interfacial instability of Li metal anodes. Here, we reveal for the first time that the thickness of the degrdn. layer on the metallic Li anode surface shows a linear relationship with Li areal capacity utilization up to 4.0 mAh cm-2 in a practical LMB system. The increase in Li capacity utilization in each cycle causes variations in the morphol. and compn. of the degrdn. layer on the Li anode. Under high Li capacity utilization, the c.d. for charge (i.e., Li deposition) is identified to be a key factor controlling the corrosion of the Li metal anode. These fundamental findings provide new perspectives for the development of rechargeable LMBs.

Enabling the reversible lithium metal electrode is essential for surpassing the energy content of today's lithium-ion cells. Although lithium metal cells for niche applications have been developed already, efforts are underway to create rechargeable lithium metal batteries that can significantly advance vehicle electrification and grid energy storage. In this Perspective, we focus on three tasks to guide and further advance the reversible lithium metal electrode. First, we summarize the state of research and com. efforts in terms of four key performance parameters, and identify addnl. performance parameters of interest. We then advocate for the use of limited lithium (≤30 μm) to ensure early identification of tech. challenges assocd. with stable and dendrite-free cycling and a more rapid transition to com. relevant designs. Finally, we provide a cost target and outline material costs and manufg. methods that could allow lithium metal cells to reach 100 US$ kWh-1.

It is widely accepted that for elec. vehicles to be accepted by consumers and to achieve wide market penetration, ranges of at least 500 km at an affordable cost are required. Therefore, significant improvements to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) in terms of energy d. and cost along the battery value chain are required, while other key performance indicators, such as lifetime, safety, fast-charging ability and low-temp. performance, need to be enhanced or at least sustained. Here, we review advances and challenges in LIB materials for automotive applications, in particular with respect to cost and performance parameters. The prodn. processes of anode and cathode materials are discussed, focusing on material abundance and cost. Advantages and challenges of different types of electrolyte for automotive batteries are examd. Finally, energy densities and costs of promising battery chemistries are critically evaluated along with an assessment of the potential to fulfil the ambitious targets of elec. vehicle propulsion.

Li-ion batteries have transformed portable electronics and will play a key role in the electrification of transport. However, the highest energy storage possible for Li-ion batteries is insufficient for the long-term needs of society, for example, extended-range elec. vehicles. To go beyond the horizon of Li-ion batteries is a formidable challenge; there are few options. Here Li-air (O2) and Li-S batteries are considered. The energy that can be stored in Li-air (based on aq. or non-aq. electrolytes) and Li-S cells is compared with Li-ion; the operation of the cells is discussed, as are the significant hurdles that will have to be overcome if such batteries are to succeed. Fundamental scientific advances in understanding the reactions occurring in the cells as well as new materials are key to overcoming these obstacles. The potential benefits of Li-air and Li-S justify the continued research effort that will be needed.

A review is given. Li-ion batteries have had a profound impact on our daily life, but inherent limitations make it difficult for Li-ion chemistries to meet the growing demands for portable electronics, elec. vehicles and grid-scale energy storage. Therefore, chemistries beyond Li-ion are currently being investigated and need to be made viable for com. applications. The use of metallic Li is one of the most favored choices for next-generation Li batteries, esp. Li-S and Li-air systems. After falling into oblivion for several decades because of safety concerns, metallic Li is now ready for a revival, thanks to the development of investigative tools and nanotechnol.-based solns. Here, we 1st summarize the current understanding on Li anodes, then highlight the recent key progress in materials design and advanced characterization techniques, and finally discuss the opportunities and possible directions for future development of Li anodes in applications.

A review. Tremendous progress has been made in the development of lithium-based rechargeable batteries in recent decades. Discoveries of new electrode materials as well as new storage mechanisms have substantially improved battery performance. In particular, nanomaterials design has emerged as a promising soln. to tackle many fundamental problems in conventional battery materials. Here we discuss in detail several key issues in batteries, such as electrode vol. change, solid-electrolyte interphase formation, electron and ion transport, and electrode atom/mol. movement, and then analyze the advantages presented by nanomaterials design. In addn., we discuss the challenges caused by using nanomaterials in batteries, including undesired parasitic reactions with electrolytes, low volumetric and areal energy d., and high costs from complex multi-step processing, and their possible solns.

A review. Li electrodes in any relevant electrolyte soln. (i.e., polar aprotic) are covered by surface films of a very complicated structure. It was found that even in cases where the surface films formed on lithium contain elastomers, or where the lithium metal reactivity is reduced by doping with elements such as N, As, Al, Mg, Ca, etc., it is impossible to achieve sufficient passivation with lithium electrodes and liq. solns. Passivation is considerably worsened when Li electrodes are operated at high rates (esp. at high charging, Li deposition rates). Thus, there is no way that rechargeable Li batteries can compete with Li-ion batteries in any application that requires high charging rates (e.g., in powering portable electronic devices). The electrochem. behavior of lithiated graphite electrodes also depends on passivation phenomena. The surface films formed on lithiated graphite are similar to those formed on Li metal in the same solns. The vol. changes of graphite electrodes during Li insertion-deinsertion are small enough to enable their reasonable passivation in a variety of electrolyte solns. A crit. factor that dets. the stability of graphite electrodes is their morphol. It was found that the shape of graphite particles plays a key role in their application as active mass in anodes for Li-ion batteries.

Dendritic growth of Li during galvanostatic electrodeposition is modeled. The time-dependent concn. distribution near the Li surface is computed by numerically solving the transport equation inside the diffusion boundary layer. The dendrite propagation rate, i.e., the dendrite tip c.d., is calcd. by analyzing the various overpotentials that develop at the dendrite tip and at the flat electrode surface. The surface overpotential at the dendrite tip due to its radius of curvature is also incorporated in the model; however, for typical dendrite tip radii, this surface overpotential is very small. The dendrite tip propagation rate predicted by the model agrees reasonably well with exptl. data from the literature. For dendritic growth under pure activation control, a simplified anal. expression for the tip c.d. is derived. The anal. expression shows that dendritic growth is suppressed in systems that exhibit a lower charge transfer coeff.

The cycling efficiencies of deposited lithium on a nickel substrate in an EC + DMC (1:1) electrolyte contg. The I-derived surface film, which consists of polymeric species, suppressed the deleterious reaction between the deposited lithium and the electrolyte.

The effects of some film-forming org. additives, fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC), vinylene carbonate (VC), and ethylene sulfite (ES), on Li deposition and dissoln. were studied in 1 M LiClO4 dissolved in propylene carbonate (PC) as a base soln. When 5% FEC was added, the cycling efficiency was improved. On the contrary, addn. of 5% VC or ES significantly lowered the cycling efficiency. The surface morphol. of Li deposited in each electrolyte soln. was obsd. by in situ at. force microscopy (AFM). In PC+FEC, the surface was covered with a uniform and closely packed layer of particle-like deposits of ∼100-150 nm diam. The surface film seemed to be more solid in PC+VC, and inhomogeneous in PC+ES. From a.c. impedance measurements, the surface film formed in PC+FEC has a lower resistance than that in the additive-free soln., whereas that formed in PC+VC or PC+ES has a higher resistance. Large vol. changes during Li deposition and dissoln. require that the surface film should be elastic (or soft) and be self-repairable when being damaged. A nonuniform current distribution is liable to cause dendrite formation, which requires that the surface film should be uniform and its resistance should be as low as possible. PC+FEC gave a surface film that satisfies all these requirements, and therefore only FEC was effective as an additive for deposition and dissoln. of Li metal.

Liquid electrolyte plays a key role in commercial lithium-ion batteries to allow conduction of lithium-ion between cathode and anode. Traditionally, taking into account the ionic conductivity, viscosity and dissolubility of lithium salt, the salt concentration in liquid electrolytes is typically less than 1.2 mol l(-1). Here we show a new class of 'Solvent-in-Salt' electrolyte with ultrahigh salt concentration and high lithium-ion transference number (0.73), in which salt holds a dominant position in the lithium-ion transport system. It remarkably enhances cyclic and safety performance of next-generation high-energy rechargeable lithium batteries via an effective suppression of lithium dendrite growth and shape change in the metallic lithium anode. Moreover, when used in lithium-sulphur battery, the advantage of this electrolyte is further demonstrated that lithium polysulphide dissolution is inhibited, thus overcoming one of today's most challenging technological hurdles, the 'polysulphide shuttle phenomenon'. Consequently, a coulombic efficiency nearing 100% and long cycling stability are achieved.

The inhomogeneous Li electrodeposition of lithium metal electrode has been a major impediment to the realization of rechargeable lithium metal batteries. Although single ion conducting ionomers can induce more homogeneous Li electrodeposition by preventing Li+ depletion at Li surface, currently available materials do not allow room-temp. operation due to their low room temp. conductivities. In the paper, we report that a highly conductive ionomer/liq. electrolyte hybrid layer tightly laminated on Li metal electrode can realize stable Li electrodeposition at high current densities up to 10 mA cm-2 and permit room-temp. operation of corresponding Li metal batteries with low polarizations. The hybrid layer is fabricated by laminating few micron-thick Nafion layer on Li metal electrode followed by soaking 1 M LiPF6 EC/DEC (1/1) electrolyte. The Li/Li sym. cell with the hybrid layer stably operates at a high c.d. of 10 mA cm-2 for more than 2000 h, which corresponds to more than five-fold enhancement compared with bare Li metal electrode. Also, the prototype Li/LiCoO2 battery with the hybrid layer offers cycling stability more than 350 cycles. These results demonstrate that the hybrid strategy successfully combines the advantages of bi-ionic liq. electrolyte (fast Li+ transport) and single ionic ionomer (prevention of Li+ depletion).

To suppress dendrite formation in lithium metal batteries, high cation transference number electrolytes that reduce electrode polarization are highly desirable, but rarely available using conventional liquid electrolytes. Here, we show that liquid electrolytes increase their cation transference numbers (e.g., ∼0.2 to >0.70) when confined to a structurally rigid polymer host whose pores are on a similar length scale (0.5-2 nm) as the Debye screening length in the electrolyte, which results in a diffuse electrolyte double layer at the polymer-electrolyte interface that retains counterions and reject co-ions from the electrolyte due to their larger size. Lithium anodes coated with ∼1 μm thick overlayers of the polymer host exhibit both a low area-specific resistance and clear dendrite-suppressing character, as evident from their performance in Li-Li and Li-Cu cells as well as in post-mortem analysis of the anode's morphology after cycling. High areal capacity Li-S cells (4.9 mg cm(-2); 8.2 mAh cm(-2)) implementing these high transference number polymer-hosted liquid electrolytes were remarkably stable, considering ∼24 μm of lithium was electroreversibly deposited in each cycle at a C-rate of 0.2. We further identified a scalable manufacturing path for these polymer-coated lithium electrodes, which are drop-in components for lithium metal battery manufacturing.

We report org.-inorg. hybrid ionic liq. electrolytes for lithium-metal secondary batteries (LMBs) and study their effect on lithium dendrite proliferation. Formed by blending silica nanoparticles densely functionalized with ionic liq. 1-methyl-3-propylimidazolium bis(trifluoromethanesulfone)imide (SiO2-IL-TFSI) with a conventional propylene carbonate/LiTFSI based liq. electrolyte, such electrolytes potentially offer at least two unique mechanisms for suppressing lithium dendrites. First, if the tethered ionic liq. mols. can dissoc. to release anions in the electrolyte, the nanoparticles might serve as reservoirs for anions in a cell, which can migrate to delay/prevent development of a space charge. Second, beyond particle concns. near the percolation threshold, the impermeable nanometer-sized particles form a porous mesh that provides a mech. strong and highly tortuous path through which nucleated dendrites must grow to short-circuit the cell. We find that at all nanoparticle compns. the SiO2-IL-TFSI/propylene carbonate hybrids exhibit substantially improved electrochem. and interfacial properties. The hybrids also show enhanced ability to retard proliferation of lithium dendrites in LMBs. We also create and characterize LMBs based on the IL-hybrid electrolytes and find that they are promising candidates for both high-energy Li/MoS2 and high-power Li/TiO2 secondary batteries.

Development of rechargeable lithium metal battery (LMB) remains a challenge because of uneven lithium deposition during repeated cycles of charge and discharge. Ionic liqs. have received intensive scientific interest as electrolytes because of their exceptional thermal and electrochem. stabilities. Ionic liq. and ionic-liq.-nanoparticle hybrid electrolytes based on 1-methy-3-propylimidazolium (IM) and 1-methy-3-propylpiperidinium (PP) were synthesized and their ionic cond., electrochem. stability, mech. properties, and ability to promote stable Li electrodeposition studied. PP-based electrolytes are more conductive and substantially more efficient in suppressing dendrite formation on cycled lithium anodes; ≥11 wt.% PP-IL in a PC-LiTFSI host produces more than a 10-fold increase in cell lifetime. Both PP- and IM-based nanoparticle hybrid electrolytes provide up to 10,000-fold improvements in cell lifetime than anticipated based on their mech. modulus alone. Galvanostatic cycling measurements in Li/Li4Ti5O12 half cells using IL-nanoparticle hybrid electrolytes reveal >500 cycles of trouble-free operation and enhanced rate capability.
